8.77.text:
- As part of a new        
      segment to the show

12.55.text:
we will be talking to        
   local authors and writers

15.38.text:
who have had an            
     impact on this region

17.82.text:
or whom this region        
     has had an impact on.

21.15.text:
This week's guest is      
      not only a founder

25.69.text:
but also a parish           
    pastor who writes about

31.76.text:
I'm proud to say today's guest 
 is Spicer resident and author

39.11.text:
- So, Doug, why don't you    
   tell me a little bit about

40.37.text:
your book, Horses in Heaven.  
  - Sure.

43.21.text:
Well, it's a story         
     about two individuals

46.75.text:
who happen to meet as they   
   are en route to Seattle.

53.42.text:
They more or less capture      
 each other's eye, if you will,

57.09.text:
and end up spending       
      four days together

61.83.text:
sharing a motel room, spending 
 the four days together.

64.73.text: At the end of that four days,

66.27.text:
they agree that they want     
  to return the following year

70.27.text:
for the same four days     
     in the month of June

76.11.text:
The story moves on        
      that they do return

78.28.text: and then for the next 40 years,

80.85.text:
they continue to          
      return for four days

84.85.text:
- And each couple chapters     
 is another year in their life

90.59.text:
- We should let the       
      audience know that

92.02.text:
you're not following       
     30 years in the life,

95.16.text:
you're following four      
     days out of a year

101.67.text:
so why don't you tell      
     us a little bit about

103.44.text:
what inspired you           
    write a book like that?

106.24.text:
Where it's not necessarily   
   the whole story

108.64.text:
but a whole story in      
      a couple chapters.

112.71.text:
it started as I was       
      doing a book signing

116.42.text:
and it was a bit slow        
   and I was people watching

119.35.text:
and I was crafting stories   
   for these people that

122.32.text:
I was watching            
      walk back and forth

129.30.text:
and that's what happens     
    in the very beginning

131.70.text:
for the female character,    
   that's how they meet,

135.57.text:
and then I began to play    
    with the whole notion

137.74.text:
what would it be like       
    for two people to meet,

142.71.text:
and then find out         
      about their stories,

144.94.text:
specifically their lives    
    just in those four days?

148.32.text:
So, the four days         
      is very intentional,

150.78.text: it became a challenge for me

152.59.text:
to figure out how can I      
   help the reader understand

155.32.text:
who these two individuals    
   are in just four days?

160.56.text:
What kind of writing styles   
  did you try to incorporate

163.40.text:
to make it a little       
      easier for yourself?

170.07.text:
I framed each             
      section of the year

173.17.text:
when they came back           
  together by historical event

176.54.text:
or using another book        
   that would give a glimpse

180.61.text:
to what that chapter       
     was going to be about,

185.55.text:
their lives would unfold    
    from that previous year

187.42.text:
based on whatever that         
 historical event or book was.

190.82.text:
- Well, and a lot of the       
 books were books that came out

194.66.text:
So, a lot of research       
    put in to make sure that

200.13.text:
And it gives you a choice to  
  pick up maybe another book

203.67.text: after you're done with this one,

206.94.text: - So, tell me a little about

208.67.text:
what kind of eyebrows were      
raised when you wrote a romance

212.71.text:
with two couples that are     
  married to different people?

219.22.text:
I don't think that was     
     really ever an issue.

224.76.text:
For me, it was to        
       engage the reader

228.09.text: to have to struggle with that

229.96.text:
because I wanted to see     
    what that would mean

233.93.text:
because both these individuals, 
as the reader finds out,

237.20.text:
really struggle in        
      their marriages for       
      a variety of things,

240.61.text:
and so, what ethical        
    issues arise from that?

244.58.text:
And what is really        
      interesting is that

247.71.text:
there are several times      
   throughout the book where

249.42.text: they have the opportunity to say

252.99.text:
let's figure out what      
     it would look like

254.65.text:
if we were to leave       
      our spouses or

257.19.text:
our spouse is no          
      longer with, living,

260.19.text: and what would that look like?

261.73.text:
And they both agreed        
    not to let that happen.

266.53.text: I think it's fair to say that

267.93.text:
they become emotionally     
    committed to each other

271.84.text:
as the book moves          
     through those 40 years

276.61.text:
and yet, there's something   
   that does not allow them

281.71.text:
to move to the next          
   level of coming together.

283.62.text:
Because early on, they      
    make the agreement that

286.72.text:
they will have absolutely    
   no contact with each other

292.32.text:
and of course, it        
       was easy in 1975,

294.09.text:
'cause you didn't have,     
    you know, internet,

296.23.text:
the cell phones, and all    
    those types of things.

299.30.text:
So, that was easier         
    than it might be today.

303.04.text:
But once they set        
       those boundaries,

305.57.text:
their relationship really had  
 boundaries like a marriage,

309.07.text: it was just a different context.

311.61.text:
- And it was just        
       kinda different,

313.38.text:
maybe kinda marriage,      
     a marriage of spirit

315.98.text:
more than a marriage      
      to each other.

318.58.text: - So, tell me a little bit,

319.95.text:
as we're talking about      
    the marriage of spirit,

323.12.text:
how you showed the       
       expression of love

326.59.text: that changes as you get older?

328.56.text:
You know, it's not       
       always just about

331.37.text:
instant gratification        
   when you're together more.

334.73.text:
- You know, and there      
     was an intentionality

336.37.text:
in the first meeting to     
    be somewhat flirtatious,

340.97.text:
lustful, I mean,         
       I really struggle,

343.94.text:
and in fact, I teach in a    
   charter school in Willmar

348.15.text:
and I shared this book that I  
 was writing with my students

351.52.text:
because I think it's      
      important for us

358.59.text:
I want you to be able      
     to read this book,

360.83.text:
so I have to be able       
     to write it, you know,

362.56.text: so it's not offensive to you,

366.00.text:
and so that, I wanted to start 
 out in a very flirtatious way

370.97.text:
but then to show how their   
   relationship of spirit

375.41.text:
and just the physicalness    
   of their relationship

384.45.text:
is no longer as          
       important in 1990

386.99.text:
or in 2014 or             
      something like that.

392.39.text:
It was about how, for        
   four days, they connected

395.39.text:
and how they used that     
     time with each other

399.40.text:
'cause they knew it       
      was just four days.

401.60.text:
And so, they had to take     
   advantage of every moment.

404.60.text:
- They had to make it last.   
  - Yeah.

406.54.text:
- For the rest of the year.   
  - For the rest of the year,

409.61.text:
- So, speaking of        
       making it last,

412.68.text:
you know, it's a          
      matter of faith when

415.28.text:
any of type of relationship,  
  friendship or otherwise,

418.48.text:
lasts more than           
      just a couple years.

422.25.text:
- So, why don't you tell us   
  about the aspect of faith

426.59.text:
Again, I wanted the reader    
  to struggle with that word,

432.97.text:
and to recognize that it's   
   something about more than

436.74.text:
simply limiting it to      
     a religious context.

441.37.text:
On the back of the       
       book, I say that

444.01.text: it's really about faith in self

448.21.text:
There is this notion        
    of them struggling with

452.79.text:
but it's really about        
   them coming to understand

457.39.text:
and then who they        
       are as a couple

460.26.text:
and how faith plays       
      a role within that.

463.80.text:
- Well, and as the title

466.90.text: it kinda gives you an idea that

469.07.text:
maybe it's not necessarily   
   just about horses

474.61.text:
it's kinda, tell us a

478.24.text:
- Well, horses are everything  
 for me, they're my passion.

And there's a             
      phrase in the book,

485.78.text:
which is a pretty common     
   phrase among horse people,

488.42.text:
that if there aren't

And there's a scene in        
  there where there's a death

498.93.text: and so, he shares that with her

502.10.text:
and that's, all at

Doug, thank you so
